All rights reserved.0039-9140TalantaVolume 74, Issue 315 December 2007Pages 333-341ReviewMicro- and Nanotechnology in Electrochemical Detection Science - dedicated to Professor Joseph Wang on the occasion of his 60th birthday - MNED 2007 SIDOI: 10.1016/j.talanta.2007.09.012PII: S0039-9140(07)00634-0333Chemical modification of polymeric microchip devices☆Alexander Muck&REcor;, a, &REemail; and Aleš SvatošaEdited by Martin Pumera and Alberto EscarpaaMass Spectrometry Research Group, Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology, Hans-Knöll-Straße 8, D-07745 Jena, GermanyReceived 1 June 2007;  revised 3 September 2007;  accepted 10 September 2007.  Available online 19 September 2007.Abstract

Analytical polymeric microchips in both fluidic and array formats offer short analysis times, coupling of many sample processing and chemical reaction steps on one platform with minimal sample and reagent consumption, as well as low cost, minimal fabrication times and disposability. However, the invariable bulk properties of most commercial polymers have driven researchers to develop new modification strategies. This article critically reviews the scope and development of chemical modifications of such polymeric chips since 2003. Surface modifications were based on chemical derivatization or activation of surface layers with reagent solutions, reactive gases and irradiation. Bulk modification of polymer chips used newly incorporation of monomers with selective chemical functionalities throughout the bulk polymer material and integrated the chip modification and fabrication into a single step. Such modifications hold a great promise for establishing a true ‘lab-on-chip’ as can be seen from many novel applications for modulating electroosmosis, suppressing protein adsorption in microchip capillary electrophoretic separations, extraction of analytes and for zone-specific binding of enzymes and other biomolecules.

Keywords: Polymer; Chemical modification; Surface; Bulk; Array; Electroosmotic flow; Adsorption; Functionalization; Enzyme; ReviewAbbreviations: AEMA, aminoethyl methacrylate; APTES, (3-aminopropyl)-triethoxysilane; BMA, butyl methacrylate; BSA, bovine serum albumin; CA I, carbonic anhydrase; CLiPP, contact liquid photolithographic polymerization; COC, cyclic olefin copolymer; Cyt C, cytochrome C; DNA, deoxyribonucleic acid; EDS, 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide; ELISA, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay; EOF, electroosmotic flow; HHem, horse hemoglobin; IgG, immunoglobulin; IMAC, immobilized metal ion affinity chromatography; LYS, lysozyme; M, molL−1; MALDI-TOF/MS, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time-of-flight mass spectrometry; MAA, methacrylic acid; MCE, microchip electrophoresis; MeCN, acetonitril; MEKC, micellar electrokinetic chromatography; MMA, methyl methacrylate; Myo, horse myoglobin; PC, poly(carbonate); PDMS, poly(dimethylsiloxane); PEGAA, poly(ethyleneglycol diacrylate); pKa, acidic dissociation constant; pMALDI, polymeric MALDI sample support array chip; PMMA, poly(methyl methacrylate); SEMA, sulfoethyl methacrylate; SPE, solid phase extraction; TRP, trypsinogen; UV, ultra violet; μeo, mobility of the electroosmotic flow; ζ, zeta potentialArticle Outline
